facts.text: Civil Appeal No.180 of 1959 was filed by certificate under Articles 132 and 133 of the Constitution against High Court order dated June 30, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No.180 of 1959. Appeal from the judgment and order dated June 30, 1955 of the former Nagpur High Court in Misc. First Appeal No. 162 of 1949.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated June 30, 1955 of Nagpur High Court in Misc. First Appeal No. 162 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated June 30, 1955 of the former Nagpur High Court in Misc. First Appeal No. 162 of 1949. C. Chatterjee and B. P. Maheshwari, for the appellant.

facts.text: In July 1922, Municipal Committee, Khandwa resolved to impose tax on trade of ginning and pressing cotton by steam or mechanical process.

anchor.surface_text: In July, 1922, the Municipal Committee, Khandwa, resolved to impose a tax on the trade of ginning and pressing cotton by means of steam, or mechanical process, and after sundry procedure,

facts.text: Notification imposing the tax published on November 25, 1922 in Central Provinces and Berar Gazette.

anchor.surface_text: a notification was published on November 25, 1922 in the Central Provinces and Berar Gazette, imposing the tax. Certain traders including the appellant, affected by the tax,

facts.text: Certain traders including appellant filed suits seeking injunction against Municipal Committee on ground tax invalid.

anchor.surface_text: Certain traders including the appellant, affected by the tax, filed suits seeking injunction against the Municipal Committee on the ground that the tax was invalid and illegal.

facts.text: Municipal Committee served notices on appellant and recovered tax for 1923-24.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, the Municipal Committee had served notices on the present appellant, and demanded and recovered the tax for 1923-24.

facts.text: Appellant filed second suit for refund of tax paid, claiming imposition illegal and ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then filed a second suit for refund of the tax paid by her on the ground that the imposition of the tax was illegal and ultra vires.

facts.text: Suits reached Privy Council; first decision remitted cases for additional evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The suits had varying fortunes in the Courts in India, till they reached the Privy Council. The Judicial Committee by its first decision remitted the cases for additional evidence,

facts.text: Privy Council second decision held tax not validly imposed, reversed Judicial Commissioner, decreed suits. Reported as Badhakishan Jaikishan v. Municipal Committee, Khandwa (1937 L.R. 64 IA 118).

anchor.surface_text: After the additional evidence was received, the Judicial Committee pronounced its decision, which is reported in Badhakishan Jaikishan v. Municipal Committee, Khandwa. The Judicial Committee held that the tax was not validly imposed

facts.text: Provincial Legislature passed Khandwa Ginning and Pressing Cotton Tax Validating Act 8 of 1938, validating the tax.

anchor.surface_text: The Provincial Legislature then passed the Khandwa Ginning and Pressing Cotton Tax Validating Act 8 of 1938, validating, the tax. The Act contained only one operative section,

facts.text: Appellant applied for execution of decrees; Validating Act 1938 pleaded in bar.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had, in the meanwhile, applied for the execution of the decrees, and the Validating Act was pleaded in bar.

facts.text: Executing Court upheld 1938 Validating Act plea, but Nagpur High Court on appeal rejected it and ordered executions to proceed. Reported as Firm Radhakishan v. Municipal Committee, Khandwa.

anchor.surface_text: This plea was upheld by the executing Court, but the High Court at Nagpur, on appeal, rejected it and ordered the executions to proceed. The decision of the High Court is reported in Firm Radhakishan v. Municipal Committee,

facts.text: Governor with assent of Governor-General enacted Khandwa Municipality Validation of Tax Act, 1941 (16 of 1941), assented June 30, 1941, published July 11, 1941.

anchor.surface_text: the Governor- with the assent of the Governor- General enacted the second Validating Act intituled the Khandwa Municipality Validation of Tax Act, 1941, 16 of 1941 , which received the assent of the Governor-General on June 30, 1941,

facts.text: 1941 Act deemed tax validly recoverable from November 21, 1922 to March 31, 1938.

anchor.surface_text: The tax the imposition of which purported to be sanctioned in the Notification ... dated the 21st November 1922, shall be, and shall be deemed always to have been, validly recoverable ... from the 21st November 1922 to the 31st March 1938 both dates inclusive.

facts.text: Municipal Committee deposited decretal amount in court, withdrawn by appellant on furnishing security.

anchor.surface_text: The Municipal Committee deposited the decretal amount in Court, which was withdrawn by the appellant on furnishing security.

facts.text: On August 7, 1947, Municipal Committee filed application under the rule for execution of the decree.

anchor.surface_text: On August 7, 1947, the Municipal Committee filed its application under the rule for execution of the decree.

facts.text: Appellant's objections to execution disallowed; Municipal Committee realised tax from surety.

anchor.surface_text: Objections were raised by the appellant, but were disallowed, and the Municipal Committee realised the amount of the tax from the surety.

facts.text: Appellant claimed 1941 Act ultra vires due to repugnancy to s.142A of Government of India Act, 1935 limiting taxes to Rs.50 after March 31, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: the Act was ultra vires the Provincial Legislature and consequently the Governor, being repugnant to s. 142-A, which was introduced in the Government of India Act, 1935, and which imposed a limit of Rs. 50 on taxes

facts.text: On November 16, 1949, appellant appealed to Nagpur High Court.

anchor.surface_text: On November 16,1949, an appeal was taken by the present appellant to the High Court at Nagpur.

facts.text: Nagpur High Court appeal heard by Sinha CJ, Mudholkar J, Deo J; Mudholkar J held Act ultra vires, Sinha CJ and Deo J contrary; appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal was heard by Sinha, C. J., and Mudholkar, J. ... Mudholkar, J. held that ... ultra vires ... Sinha C., J., was of the contrary opinion. The case was then laid before Deo, J., who agreed with Sinha, C. J., and the appeal was dismissed.

facts.text: Appellant obtained certificate and filed appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then obtained the certificate, and filed this appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court held 1941 Validating Act within powers of Governor and valid legislation.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the Validating Act of 1941 was within the powers of the Governor, and was a valid piece of legislation.

The Act companytained only one operative section, which read as follows Notwithstanding anything companytained in the Central Provinces Municipal Act, 1903, or the Central Province Municipalities Act, 1922, or any decree or order of a civil companyrt, the tax on the trade of ginning and pressing companyton by means of steam or mechanical process within the limits of the Khandwa municipality which was imposed by Notification No. 2639-1298- VIII, dated the 21st November, 1922, shall be deemed to have been legally imposed from the date of its imposition to the date on which this Act companyes into force.

anchor.surface_text: the Governor- with the assent of the Governor- General enacted the second Validating Act intituled the Khandwa Municipality  Validation of Tax  Act, 1941, 16 of 1941 , which received the assent of the Governor-General on June 30, 1941, and was published in the C. P. and Berar Gazette on July 11, 1941. That Act, omitting parts number relevant here, read as follows The tax the imposition of which purported to be sanctioned in the Notification of the Local Government  Ministry of Local Self- Government  No. 2639-1298-VIII, dated the 21st November 1922, shall be, and shall be deemed always to have been, validly recoverable by the Municipal Committee of Khandwa in respect of the period from the 21st November 1922 to the 31st March 1938  both dates inclusive . Where the net sum recovered from any person before the companymencement of this Act on account of the said tax is less than the aggregate of the sum recoverable from such person, the balance shall be payable to the said Municipal Committee on demand made at any time after the companymencement of this Act and, if number paid within fifteen days from the date of the demand, shall be recoverable by any method available under the Central Provinces Municipalities Act,, 1922, for the recovery of a tax imposed thereunder or by such other method as the Provincial Government may by rule prescribe.

anchor.surface_text: Retrospective laws, it has been held, can validate an Act, which companytains some defect in its enactment. issues.text: whether the Act was ultra vires the Provincial Legislature and consequently the Governor, being repugnant to s. 142-A, which was introduced in the Government of India Act, 1935, and which imposed a limit of Rs. 50 on taxes on professions, trades and callings after March 31, 1939

anchor.surface_text: the Act was ultra vires the Provincial Legislature and companysequently the Governor, being repugnant to a. 142-A, which was introduced in the Government of India Act, 1935, and which imposed a limit of Rs. 50 on taxes on professions, trades and callings after March 31, 1939. On November 16,1949, an appeal was taken by the present appellant to the High Court at Nagpur. This appeal was heard by Sinha, C. J., and Mudholkar, J.

issues.text: The only question thus is whether the power to pass a retrospective and validating law was taken away by the enactment of s. 142-A and the amendment of the Entry in the Government of India Act

anchor.surface_text: The same can be said of the Provincial Legislatures and also of the Governor acting as a Legislature. The only question thus is whether the power to pass a retrospective and validating law was taken away by the enactment of s. 142-A and the amendment of the Entry in the Government of India Act. It is on this point that the difference in the High Court arose. The amendment of the Entry is of numberspecial significance,

issues.text: whether by the second Validating Act which was passed after March 31, 1939, the limit of Rs. 50 per annum imposed by the second sub-section of s. 142-A was exceeded

anchor.surface_text: Mudholkar, J. held that by the second Validating Act which was passed after March 31, 1939, the limit of Rs. 50 per annum imposed by the second sub-section of s. 142-A was exceeded, and that the Act was thus ultra vires, the Governor. Sinha C., J., was of the companytrary opinion.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. N. C. Chatterjee, in arguing the case, adopted the line of reasoning of the minority view in the High Court. He pointed out that s. 142-A was enacted to achieve three purposes. The first was that it removed doubts whether the charge of tax on professions, etc., would be regarded as income-tax.

holdings.text: The Validating Act of 1941 was within the powers of the Governor, and was a valid piece of legislation.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the Validating Act of 1941 was within the powers of the Governor, and was a valid piece of legislation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.142A(2) limits taxes payable only after March 31, 1939; 1941 Act validates pre-1939 period retrospectively within plenary powers under Entry 46; Governor under s.90 has equivalent powers.

holdings.text: The power to pass a retrospective and validating law was not taken away by the enactment of s. 142-A and the amendment of Entry 46.

anchor.surface_text: The only question thus is whether the power to pass a retrospective and validating law was taken away by the enactment of s. 142-A and the amendment of the Entry in the Government of India Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amendment subjects plenary powers only to s.142A provisions, which confine limits to post-March 31, 1939; no prohibition on retrospective validation for prior period.

holdings.text: The powers of Provincial Legislatures under Legislative Lists are as large and plenary as those of Parliament itself, including power to make retrospective laws.

anchor.surface_text: The powers of the Provincial Legislatures under the Legislative Lists have been the subject of numerous decisions by the Federal Court and also by this Court. It has been pointed out that these powers are as large and plenary as those of Parliament itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Established by Federal Court and Supreme Court precedents; burden to prove restriction on retrospectivity not met.

holdings.text: s.292 of the Government of India Act, 1935 does not prevent legislatures from giving retrospective effect to measures.

anchor.surface_text: This view was not accepted by the Federal Court, which held that s. 292 of the Act did not prevent Legislatures in India from giving retrospective effect to measures passed by them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Federal Court rejected Allahabad HC view in Atiqa Begum case.

holdings.text: Power of validating defective laws is ancillary and subsidiary to powers conferred by legislative entries; can render court decrees inoperative.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Federal Court in Atiqa Begum and Piare Dusadh affirmed as included in plenary powers.

holdings.text: The limit in s.142A(2) applies only to total amount payable after March 31, 1939; does not prohibit validation of pre-1939 taxes.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading confines prohibition to post-date; plenary power otherwise permits retrospective for prior period.

holdings.text: Act passed by Governor under s.90 GOI Act 1935 has same force as Provincial Legislature Act; complied with Governor-General assent.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned Act was passed by the Governor under s. 90 of the Government of India Act, 1935. Under sub-s. (3) of that section, it had the same force and effect... The impugned Act was enacted with the concurrence and assent of the Governor-General

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.90(3); formalities satisfied.

precedents.citation: The United Provinces v. Atiqa Begum 1

anchor.surface_text: Gwyer, C.J. in The United Provinces v. Atiqa Begum  1 , the burden of proving that Indian Legislatures were subject to a strange and unusual prohibition against retrospective legislation lay upon those who asserted it.

precedents.cited_proposition: burden of proving prohibition against retrospective legislation on those asserting it
precedents.cited_holding: Indian Legislatures have power to make retrospective laws

precedents.citation: Mst. Atiqa Begum v. U. P. 2

anchor.surface_text: the case before the Allahabad High Court, out of which the appeal before the Federal Court had arisen sub number Mst. Atiqa Begum v. U. P.  2 , it was held that retrospective legislation was number possible

precedents.case_name: Mst Atiqa Begum v U P
precedents.cited_proposition: retrospective legislation not possible due to s.292 of Government of India Act 1935

precedents.citation: M. P. V. Sundararamier Co. The State of Andhra Pradesh 3

precedents.case_name: MPV Sundararamier & Co v State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: approved Federal Court dictum on power to make retrospective laws

anchor.surface_text: Retrospective laws, it has been held, can validate an Act, which companytains some defect in its enactment. Examples of Validating Acts which rendered inoperative, decrees or orders of the Court or alternatively made them valid and effective, are many. In Atiqa Begums case  1 , the power

precedents.cited_proposition: power of validating defective laws is ancillary and subsidiary to powers conferred by legislative entries

anchor.surface_text: Later, the Federal Court in Piare Dusadh,v. King Emperor  2  companysidered the matter fully, and held that the powers of the Governor General which were companyterminous with those of the Central Legislature included the power of validation.

precedents.cited_proposition: powers of Governor-General coterminous with Central Legislature include power of validation
